Hi thanks for the report.
This is the intended behavior for oauth authorization. When you sent the request link to your friend (or another browser on your machine) to let Account A authorize the 3rd-party app to use the account, such authorization is bind with the request token (i.e., the oauth_token in https://api.twitter.com/oauth/authenticate?oauth_token=xxxxxxxx). Thus, when Account A login and click the button to give the authorization. It is supposed behavior that the third-party app/website will be able to get the oauth access token and then let a browser which has sent the request_token to login. It doesn't have additional security threat, because Account A needs to explicitly grant the authorization access.
Thus, we do not plan to make changes regarding this report.

Thanks for thinking of Twitter security!
